title: Yellowstone National Park: Permits & Reservations
body: Explore This Park    Plan Your Visit     Basic Information     Permits & Reservations               Permits & Reservations       Reservations  No advance reservations are needed to enter the park For lodging and camping reservations inside the park, contact Xanterra Parks & Resorts Be sure to check for opening and closing dates for facilities inside the park Lodging can fill months in advance. Make your reservations early For information on lodging or camping outside the park, visit our Nearby Attractions page.        Permits  Fishing Permits Backcountry Permits Boating Permits Research Permits Wedding Information Ash Scattering Guidelines (35 KB PDF) Stock entry into the park requires Coggins testing  Commercial Use Permits  Film, Photography and Sound Recording Permits Commercial Travel Permits (238 KB PDF)  Credit Card Payment Form  Payment Form for Special Park Uses (653 KB PDF)  Special Use Permits (SUP)  General SUP Application (74 KB PDF)  Certain types of activities require a special use permit. These include many types of organized gatherings, distribution of printed material and other public expressions of opinion, and other activities that are controlled or prohibited. See the following definitions and examples to determine if your use might be included: A special park use is defined as a short-term activity that takes place in a park area, and that:  provides a benefit to an individual, group or organization rather than the public at large; requires written authorization and some degree of management control from the National Park Service (NPS) in order to protect park resources and the public interest; is not prohibited by law or regulation; is not initiated, sponsored, or conducted by the NPS; and is not managed under a concession contract, a recreation activity for which the NPS charges a fee, or a lease.  Examples include: weddings, other ceremonies, or public assemblies, etc. Examples of a First-Amendment Activity include: a church service or Freedom-of-Speech act. For more information regarding Special Use Permits or to determine if your activity requires one, please call 307-344-2115 or email the park with the subject line "Attn: Special Use Permits." Applications for permits should be submitted well in advance, preferably 2-3 months before event, for consideration and processing.       More Information  Campgrounds in Yellowstone: Detailed information on Yellowstone campgrounds.
